s.text: When the film begins, in the early '30s, he (played by Tim Roth) is a white Prohibition beer baron who has muscled his way into the neighborhood numbers racket, shutting down competitors or forcing them to join his operation.

Since the game never favored the players, the "bankers" naturally amassed large profits.
Since the game never favored the players, the "bankers" naturally amassed large profits.

A player won if his number matched an agreed-upon daily variable made known through some public channel--for example, the last three digits of the total amount wagered at a given racetrack, which anyone could learn through the sports pages.

A player won if his number matched an agreed-upon daily variable made known through some public channel--for example, the last three digits of the total amount wagered at a given racetrack, which anyone could learn through the sports pages.
The numbers game was an illegal daily lottery--particularly popular in Harlem--in which, typically, players chose a number from zero to 999 and placed bets through "policy banks."

A player won if his number matched an agreed-upon daily variable made known through some public channel--for example, the last three digits of the total amount wagered at a given racetrack, which anyone could learn through the sports pages.

A player won if his number matched an agreed-upon daily variable made known through some public channel--for example, the last three digits of the total amount wagered at a given racetrack, which anyone could learn through the sports pages.
In life, Schultz's murder was ordered by the national criminal syndicate formed by Luciano and the famed mobster Meyer Lansky.
Viewers are left with the impression that Johnson orchestrated the killing.
(1971) that St. Clair herself stood up to Schultz, even asking city officials to crack down on his racket.
And in 1935, when Schultz was dying in a Newark hospital, having been gunned down in a mob hit, St. Clair sent a Western Union message: "As ye sow, so shall ye reap."
Dutch Schultz and Lucky Luciano are renowned figures, staples of crime books and studies.
